title: Gravity and a universal cutoff for field theory
abstract:
We analyze the one-loop effects of massive fields on 2-to-2 scattering
processes involving gravitons. It has been suggested that in the presence of
gravity, any local effective field theory description must break down at the
"species scale". We first observe that unitarity and analyticity of the
amplitude indeed imply a species-type bound $G\Lambda^{d-2}N\leq O(1)$, where
$N$ counts parametrically light species and $\Lambda$ is an energy scale above
which new unknown ingredients must modify the graviton amplitude. To clarify
what happens at this scale, we contrast the partial wave decomposition of
calculated amplitudes with that of some ultraviolet scenarios: string theory
and strongly interacting Planck-scale physics. Observing that the latter
exhibit a markedly stronger high-spin content, we define nonperturbatively the
high-spin onset scale $\Lambda_{\rm o}$, which coincides with the string scale
and higher-dimensional Planck scale in respective examples. We argue that,
generally, no local field description can exist at distances shorter than
$1/\Lambda_{\rm o}$.
